layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates tree cover along walkable roads. The road width is estimated for each road and percent tree cover is calculated in a 8.5 meter strip beginning at the estimated road edge. Percent tree cover is calculated for each block between road intersections. Tree cover provides valuable benefits to neighborhood residents and walkers by providing shade, improved aesthetics, and outdoor gathering spaces.

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the acres of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that are enrolled in the US Department of Agriculture's Conservation Reserve Program (CRP). The CRP is a program administered by the Farm Service Agency; farmers in the program receive annual payments and establishment cost share to remove environmentally sensitive land from crop production and instead plant perennial species that provide environmental benefits.

fieldInfos.label: Acres of land enrolled in CRP

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 45 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forests for 2011.
layer.name: Percent forest land in stream buffer

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest land in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1 and 2

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1, 2, and 3

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is designated as Status 3 under the USGS Gap Analysis Program for 2011. These areas have permanent protection from conversion of natural land cover for the majority of area. Subject to extractive uses of either broad, low-intensity type (e.g.. Logging) or localized intense type (e.g., Mining). Confers protection to federally listed endangered and threatened species throughout the area.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 3

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is impervious for 2011. Impervious surfaces do not allow the penetration of water and include buildings, roads, and sidewalks.
layer.name: Percent impervious area

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IA by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IA protected areas seek to protect biodiversity and natural features; human visitation, use, and impacts are strictly controlled.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IA
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IB by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IB protected areas include large unmodified or slightly modified areas, without permanent or significant human habitation. These lands are protected and managed so as to protect their natural condition.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IB
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status II by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category II protected areas re large natural or near natural areas set aside to protect large-scale ecological processes, along with the complement of species and ecosystems characteristic of the area, which also provide a foundation for environmentally and culturally compatible, spiritual, scientific, educational, recreational, and visitor opportunities.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status II
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status III by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category III protected areas are set aside to protect a specific natural monument, which can be a landform, sea mount, submarine cavern, geological feature such as a cave or even a living feature such as an ancient grove. They are generally quite small protected areas and often have high visitor value.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status III
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IV by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IV areas aim to protect particular species or habitats and management reflects this priority. Many Category IV protected areas will need regular, active interventions to address the requirements of particular species or to maintain habitats, but this is not a requirement of the category.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IV
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status V by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category V protected areas have distinct character with significant, ecological, biological, cultural and scenic value: and where safeguarding the integrity of this interaction is vital to protecting and sustaining the area and its associated nature conservation and other values.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status V
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status VI by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category VI protected areas are generally large, with most of the area in a natural condition, where a proportion is under sustainable natural resource management and where low-level non-industrial use of natural resources compatible with nature conservation is seen as one of the main aims of the area.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status VI
eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is protected. It includes all lands that have been classified by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as protected areas for 2011.
layer.name: Percent land with any IUCN status

fieldInfos.label: Percent land with any IUCN status

eaTags: "International Union for the Conservation of Nature"

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by large patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Large natural areas are greater than 25,000 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

fieldInfos.label: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by medium sized patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Medium natural areas are less 25,000 acres but greater than 500 acres and are covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover

fieldInfos.label: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has natural land cover for 2011. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and impervious surfaces.
layer.name: Percent natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 45 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is naturally covered for 2011. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent natural land cover in stream buffer

fieldInfos.label: Percent natural land cover in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that could be classified as rare ecosystem forms that is protected for 2011. Ecosystem rarity in EnviroAtlas is based on size, shape, and type of ecosystem.
layer.name: Percent of rare ecosystem forms protected

fieldInfos.label: Percent of rare ecosystem forms protected

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of stream and water body shoreline lengths that had impervious cover greater than or equal to 15% within 30 meters for 2011.
layer.name: Percent of stream and shoreline with 15% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

fieldInfos.label: Percent of stream and shoreline with 15% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of stream and water body shoreline lengths that had impervious cover greater than or equal to 5% within 30 meters for 2011.
layer.name: Percent of stream and shoreline with 5% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

fieldInfos.label: Percent of stream and shoreline with 5% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land managed as pasture in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. Pasture areas are planted for livestock grazing or the production of seed or hay crops.
layer.name: Percent pasture

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that may be suitable for wetland restoration and is on agricultural land for 2011.
layer.name: Percent potentially restorable wetlands on agricultural land

fieldInfos.label: Percent potentially restorable wetlands on agricultural land

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by range land for 2011. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. EnviroAtlas defines range as land dominated by shrubs or herbaceous vegetation.
layer.name: Percent range in areas with high water accumulation

fieldInfos.label: Percent range in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that could be classified as rare ecosystem forms for 2011. Ecosystem rarity in EnviroAtlas is based on size, shape, and type of ecosystem.
layer.name: Percent rare ecosystem forms

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by small patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Small natural areas are less 500 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent small size patches of natural land cover

fieldInfos.label: Percent small size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land comprised of woody and emergent herbaceous wetlands in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For this map, EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database and its definitions of woody and emergent herbaceous wetlands.
layer.name: Percent wetlands

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by wetlands for 2011. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database classification of wetlands.
layer.name: Percent wetlands in areas with high water accumulation

fieldInfos.label: Percent wetlands in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total population that lives within 90 meters of a major road with little to no tree buffer for 2011.
layer.name: Population near major roadway with little to no tree buffer

fieldInfos.label: Population near roadway with little to no tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the drainage density within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2015-2016. The density is equal to the total stream length in kilometers within a subwatershed divided by its total area in square kilometers.
layer.name: Stream density (km/km2)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total kilometers of streams, rivers, or other linear waterways within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2015-2016. It includes both natural and man-made water features, but excludes non-linear waterbodies such as lakes.
layer.name: Stream length (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by mercury for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by mercury (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to the presence of metals other than mercury in the water for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by metals other than mercury (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by metals other than mercury (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by algal growth, noxious aquatic plants, and nuisance native or invasive plants, animals, fish, or microbes for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by nuisance species (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by nuisance species (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to the presence of nutrients in the water for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by nutrients (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by excessive organic materials or reduced oxygen for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by organic enrichment or oxygen depletion (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by organic enrichment or oxygen depletion (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by microbes, such as bacteria, that can spread disease for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pathogens (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by pesticides, such as herbicide and insecticide for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pesticides (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to being too acidic or too alkaline for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pH, acidity, or caustic conditions (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by pH, acidity, or caustic conditions (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by sediment or turbidity for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by sediment or turbidity (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by sediment or turbidity (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired for having higher than average temperature for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired for temperature (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to any other cause, including flow alterations, habitat alterations, ammonia, biotoxins, chlorine, dioxins, oil and grease, PCBs, radiation, salinity, toxic substances, trash, taste, color, or odor for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length with any other impairment (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length with any other impairment (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired for biota, including fish kills and fish consumption advisory for 2015-2016. Biota or biological impairment is an indication of water quality and not the source of impairment.
layer.name: Stream length with impaired biota (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the mean rate of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer application to agricultural lands within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kg N/ha/yr for 2006.
layer.name: Synthetic nitrogen fertilizer application (kg N/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total annual deposition of nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of oxidized and reduced nitrogen.
layer.name: Total annual nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual  deposition of oxidized nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of oxidized nitrogen.
layer.name: Total annual oxidized nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual deposition of reduced nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of reduced nitrogen.
layer.name: Total annual reduced nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual deposition of sulfur within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of sulfur.
layer.name: Total annual sulfur deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species observered associated with aquatic habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Total number of at-risk aquatic species observed

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk aquatic species

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species observered associated with terrestrial habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe. Terrestrial habitat refers to land areas such as forests, grasslands, deserts and rainforests.
layer.name: Total number of at-risk terrestrial species observed

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk terrestrial species

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species observered associated with wetland habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe.
layer.name: Total number of at-risk wetland species observed

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk wetland species

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts annual sales in dollars for cotton produced within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Value of cotton crops (dollars/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts annual sales in dollars for major grain crops produced within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Value of grain crops (dollars/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the thousands of tons of vegetable crops that are grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2010.
layer.name: Vegetable yields (thousand tons/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the millions of gallons of surface water in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is contained in the 2009 National Inventory of Dams reservoirs and/or behind dams. This map only estimates volume and does not take into account water rights, designated uses, or previous appropriations.
layer.name: Water supply from NID reservoirs (million gallons)

fieldInfos.label: Water supply from NID reservoirs (million gallons)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total square kilometers of lakes, ponds, reservoirs, estuaries, playas, swamps, and marshes within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC).
layer.name: Waterbody area (km2)

layer.eaDescription: The EnviroAtlas Potential Wetland Areas (PWA) dataset shows potential wetland areas at 30-meter resolution. Beginning two centuries ago, many wetlands were turned into farm fields or urban areas, yet wetlands play an important role in removing water pollution, regulating water storage and flows, and providing habitat for wildlife. Wetland restoration could help restore these benefits. Potential wetland areas, as developed for this map, are lands that naturally accumulate water due to topography and have historically had poorly or very poorly draining soils. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to the EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
layer.name: Potential Wetland Area

fieldInfos.label: Potentially Restorable Wetlands on Agricultural Land

popup.title: Potentially Restorable Wetlands on Agricultural Land

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset shows potentially restorable wetlands at 30 meter resolution. Potentially restorable wetlands for this map are lands currently in agriculture that naturally accumulate water and historically had poor drainage and hydric soils.
layer.name: Potentially Restorable Wetlands on Agricultural Land

layer.eaDescription: This map for rare ecosystems in the conterminous U.S. delineates the Relative Rarity Metric developed by the EPA. The metric is based on current extent, spatial pattern type, and relative uniqueness. Metric values range from 0 to 100 with higher values indicating greater relative ecosystem rarity.
layer.name: Rare Ecosystems

popup.title: MSPA Water as Background with 30m edge

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts protected areas, defined as lands dedicated to and actively managed for the preservation of biological diversity, recreation, and cultural uses, from the U.S. Protected Areas Database (PADUS). The protected lands in this map are categorized according to International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) management categories for protected areas.
eaTags: International Union for Conservation of Nature
layer.name: IUCN Category (Land Protection Status (IUCN))

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts protected areas, defined as lands dedicated to and actively managed for the preservation of biological diversity, recreation, and cultural uses, from the U.S. Protected Areas Database (PADUS). The protected lands in this map are categorized according to USGS Gap Analysis Program (GAP) Status Code.
layer.name: GAP Status Code (Land Protection Status (GAP))

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts protected areas, defined as lands dedicated to and actively managed for the preservation of biological diversity, recreation, and cultural uses, from the U.S. Protected Areas Database (PADUS). The protected lands in this map are categorized according to the type of agency that manages the area.
layer.name: General Land Ownership

layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2011 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that has been applied consistently across the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.
layer.name: National Land Cover Database (NLCD 2011 Conterminous US Only)

layer.eaDescription: This layer is derived from the 2018 version of the gSSURGO 30m (contiguous 48 States and Washington D.C.) and 10m rasters (all other regions) produced by the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS). The value for drainage class is derived from the gSSURGO map unit aggregated attribute table field Drainage Class - Dominant Condition (drclassdcd). The SSURGO variable natural drainage class (dominant condition) was selected for use in EnviroAtlas because it indicates soil wetness or degree of saturation.
layer.name: Soils Drainage Class - dominant condition

layer.eaDescription: These maps identify waterbodies that have been assessed and determined to be impaired, meaning that the waterbody has been degraded and does not meet the standards for seven designated beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). This map identifies area features from the Impaired Waters database.
layer.name: Impaired Waters

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts waterbodies that have been assessed by states, territories, and authorized tribes every two years to evaluate waterbody condition for seven beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). Those waterbodies not meeting the standards for beneficial uses are designated as impaired or threatened. This map identifies area features from the Assessed Waters database.
layer.name: Assessed Waters

layer.eaDescription: This National Wetlands Inventory (NWI) map, developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, maps and classifies wetlands across the U.S. State and local government agencies use NWI in planning to identify local wetlands and to limit and mitigate wetland losses during economic development.
layer.name: Wetlands (National Wetlands Inventory)

layer.eaDescription: This dataset contains polygons and points representing the location of markets and projects primarily targeting watershed-related ecosystem services per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Polygons for projects represent the project footprint (i.e. land area comprising the project site) or area of primary impact. Polygons for markets represent the entire region that shares market infrastructure and rules, or a larger program encompassing many smaller projects. Points represent the centroids of market and project polygons with the exception of national markets, whose points represent administrative headquarters locations.

layer.eaDescription: Nonbuffered agriculture as a percentage of total land area in the HUC12
layer.name: Percent nonbuffered agriculture

layer.eaDescription: Buffered agriculture as a percentage of total agriculture in each 12-digit HUC.
layer.name: Percent of agriculture that is buffered

fieldInfos.label: Percent of agriculture that is buffered

layer.eaDescription: The average width in meters of buffers that are contiguous to the stream and are intersected by agricultural flow paths. This metric does not include any riparian areas that do not also contain agriculture upslope.
layer.name: Average width of stream buffers downstream from agriculture

fieldInfos.label: Average width of stream buffers downstream from agriculture.

layer.eaDescription: Mean rental rate for irrigated land on record by county, measured in $/acre for approximately 2008-2016.
layer.name: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Irrigated

fieldInfos.label: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Irrigated

layer.eaDescription: Mean rental rate for non-irrigated land on record by county, measured in $/acre for approximately 2008-2016.
layer.name: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Non-irrigated

fieldInfos.label: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Non-irrigated

layer.eaDescription: Mean rental rate for pastureland on record by county, measured in $/acre for approximately 2008-2016.
layer.name: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Pasture

fieldInfos.label: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016 Pasture

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the mean phosphorus (P) balance between P inputs on croplands from inorganic fertilizer and manure, and removal of P by crops in kilograms P per hectare per year within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2012.
layer.name: Net agricultural phosphorus balance (kg P/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the mean crop phosphorus (P) removal from croplands in kilograms P per hectare per year within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2012.
layer.name: Crop phosphorus removal (kg P/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the application rate of inorganic phosphorus (P) fertilizer on agricultural land in kilograms P per hectare per year within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2012.
layer.name: Phosphorus fertilizer application (kg P/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the application rate of phosphorus (P) as manure on croplands in kilograms P per hectare per year within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2012.
layer.name: Phosphorus application as manure (kg P/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the number of Candidate Ecological Restoration Areas (CERAs) per square kilometer. CERAs are areas that could be restored to connect large vegetated areas. They were identified using morphological spatial pattern analysis.
layer.name: Candidate Ecological Restoration Areas per square kilometer.

fieldInfos.label: Candidate Ecological Restoration Areas per square kilometer.

layer.eaDescription: These polygons represent candidate areas for ecological restoration, based on potential to improve connectivity between naturally vegetated areas.
layer.name: Candidate Ecological Restoration Areas

fieldInfos.label: Total hectares of connected area (excluding the potential restored area)
Hectares of second largest connected area
Contribution of the second largest vegetated region to the combined vegetated area
Mean cation exchange capacity (meq / 100g soil),0-5 cm depth
Mean cation exchange capacity (meq / 100g soil),5-20 cm depth
Percent islet (small vegetated areas not surrounded by similar land cover)
Potential restored area in square meters

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as pasture on areas with slopes greater than or equal to three percent
layer.name: Percent pasture on slopes >= 3%

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as pasture on areas with slopes greater than or equal to nine percent.
layer.name: Percent pasture on slopes >= 9%

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as cropland on areas with slopes greater than or equal to three percent.
layer.name: Percent cropland on slopes >= 3%

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as cropland on areas with slopes greater than or equal to nine percent.
layer.name: Percent cropland on slopes >= 9%

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen dissolved in surface runoff at the outer edges of all agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N for 2002. It includes nitogen from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in surface runoff from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nutrients in surface runoff from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

It includes phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in surface runoff from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nutrients in surface runoff from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen dissolved in sub-surface (lateral) flow at the outer edges of non-tile drained agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N for 2002. It includes nitogen from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nitrogen in non-tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons)

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nitrogen in non-tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons)

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen dissolved in sub-surface (lateral) flow at the outer edges of tile drained agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N for 2002. It includes nitogen from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nutrients in tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of phosphorus dissolved in sub-surface (lateral) flow at the outer edges of tile-drained agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of P for 2002. It includes phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen attached to soil particles eroding from the surface of the agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N for 2002. It includes nitrogen from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Nutrients attached to eroding surface soil from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

fieldInfos.label: Nutrients attached to eroding surface soil from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of phosphorus attached to soil particles eroding from the surface of the agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of P for 2002. It includes phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Nutrients attached to eroding surface soil from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

fieldInfos.label: Nutrients attached to eroding surface soil from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of nitrogen leachate, i.e., mass of nitrogen dissolved in percolate moving downward out of the soil layer underlying agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N for 2002. It does not necessarily reflect the amount of nitrogen that actually enters an underlying groundwater reservoir.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in leachate from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nutrients in leachate from agricultural fields (tons) Nitrogen

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of phosphorus leachate, i.e., mass of phosphorus dissolved in percolate moving downward out of the soil layer underlying agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of P for 2002. It does not necessarily reflect the amount of nitrogen that actually enters an underlying groundwater reservoir.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in leachate from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

fieldInfos.label: Dissolved nutrients in leachate from agricultural fields (tons) Phosphorus

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of sub-surface (lateral) flow at the outer edges of tile drained agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in millimeters (mm) of water for 2002.
layer.name: Subsurface water flow through agricultural tile drainage systems (mm)

fieldInfos.label: Subsurface water flow through agricultural tile drainage systems (mm)

layer.name: Non-tile drainage system subsurface water flow from agricultural lands (mm)

layer.eaDescription: This map provides modeled estimates of percolation (vertical) flow from the bottom of the soil layer underlying agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in millimeters (mm) of water for 2002. It does not necessarily reflect the amount of water that actually enters an underlying groundwater reservoir.

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted discharges for all weighable parameters within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in pounds for 2011. The Loading Tool includes approximately 1,000 pollutant parameters including specific chemicals (e.g., phenol), bulk parameters (e.g., biochemical oxygen demand), temperature, and wastewater flow. However, these pollutants do not account for all pollutants discharged to U.S. waters. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Total permitted discharges - pounds per year

fieldInfos.label: Total permitted discharges - pounds per year

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted discharges within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011, expressed as toxic-weighted pound-equivalents (TWPE). TWPE is the mass of a pollutant or chemical discharged that accounts for its relative toxicity. To convert pollutant loadings into TWPE, EPA multiplies the pollutant mass (in pounds) by its pollutant specific toxic weighting factor (TWF). Not all pollutants have a toxic weighting factor (for example, Total Suspended Solids), which means that these pollutants do not have a toxicity score (i.e., TWPE = 0). (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Total permitted discharges - toxic-weighted pound-equivalents

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted pollutant loadings for metals parameters within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011, in pounds. Hexavalent or trivalent metals and metals in ionic form (e.g., hexavalent chromium and aluminum, ion) are included, but metal compounds (e.g., calcium chloride) are not included. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Permitted metals discharges - pounds per year

fieldInfos.label: Permitted metals discharges - pounds per year

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates the intersection density of walkable roads within a 750 meter radius of any given 10 meter pixel in the community. Intersections are defined as any point where 3 or more roads meet and density is calculated using kernel density, where closer intersections are weighted higher than further intersections. Intersection density is highly correlated with walking for transportation.
layer.name: Estimated intersection density of walkable roads

fieldInfos.label: Estimated intersection density of walkable roads

layer.eaDescription: This dataset includes data from facilities reporting to EPA - Air Pollution: The air pollution data (ICIS-AIR, ICIS-AIR Major) contains compliance and permit data for stationary sources of air pollution (such as electric power plants, steel mills, factories, and universities) regulated by EPA, state and local air pollution agencies.

layer.eaDescription: Landscape Conservation Cooperatives (LCCs) are represented in this map by 22 regions established across the U.S., Alaska, Hawaii, and U.S. territories. LCC groups are created through conservation and science partnerships between federal agencies, states, tribes, non-governmental organizations, universities, and private stakeholders.
layer.name: Landscape Conservation Cooperatives

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates USEPA (Omernik) Level III and IV ecoregions, a geographic framework used for an ecosystem approach to land and water resource management. Ecoregions define relatively homogeneous geographical areas that contain similarities in the character of environmental resources.
layer.name: USEPA Ecoregions (Omernik)

layer.eaDescription: The GAP (Gap Anlaysis Program) Ecological Systems data layer, one of several data layers available in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) GAP Land Cover Dataset, depicts native vegetation, agricultural areas, and urban development in 590 land use classes. Ecological Systems refers to the vegetation classification developed by NatureServe to map the natural vegetation of the U.S. Separate Ecological Systems datasets have been created for Alaska (LANDFIRE) and Hawaii (Hawaii Gap Analysis Project).
layer.name: GAP Ecological Systems

layer.eaDescription: Surface water identified in EnviroAtlas' hybrid National Land Cover Database-Cropland Data Layer or the NHDPlusV2 catseed grid. The land cover classes, 'Open Water', 'Woody Wetlands', and 'Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands' were considered surface water.
layer.name: Waterscape - Surface water

layer.eaDescription: Raster showing the hydrologically connected zone, defined as surface water plus any connected cells with high water acculmulation. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet.

layer.eaDescription: Raster showing the riparian zone, defined as land within 108 meters of surface water identified in the NHDPlusV2 catseed grid or in EnviroAtlas' hybrid National Land Cover Database-Cropland Data Layer (including 'Open Water', 'Woody Wetlands', and 'Emergent Herbaceous Wetlands').
layer.name: Waterscape - Riparian zone

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of oxidized nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry nitrogen to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual oxidized nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of reduced nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry nitrogen to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual reduced nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of sulfur within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry sulfur to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual sulfur deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness for bird species listed by Partners in Flight in their Watch List for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Modeled Partners in Flight Watch List bird species

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness for Birds of Conservation Concern for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The Bird of Conservation Concern Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area.
layer.name: Modeled State of the Birds species of conservation concern

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict threatened and endangered species richness for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Modeled threatened and endangered vertebrate species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model Audubon Climate Endangered bird species (https://climate.audubon.org/) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US   as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These are bird species vulnerable to a loss of 50% or more of current range due to climate change by 2050. These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Number of bird species vulnerable to range loss due to climate change by 2050

layer.eaDescription: These maps model Audubon Climate Threatened bird species (https://climate.audubon.org/) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These are bird species vulnerable to a loss of 50% or more of current range due to climate change by 2080. These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Number of bird species vulnerable to range loss due to climate change by 2080

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of observed species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with aquatic habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Number of observed at-risk aquatic species

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of observed species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with terrestrial habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe. Terrestrial habitat refers to land areas such as forests, grasslands, deserts and rainforests.
layer.name: Number of observed at-risk terrestrial species

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of observed species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with wetland habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe.
layer.name: Number of observed at-risk wetland species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model amphibian species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Amphibian species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model bird species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Bird species richness

layer.name: Reptile species richness

layer.name: Total vertebrate species richness

layer.name: Big game species richness

layer.name: Fur bearer species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model small game species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Small game species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model harvestable species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Total harvestable species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model waterfowl species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Waterfowl species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the average reduction in the ambient temperature at 2pm on a hot summer day (daytime) or  at night following a hot summer day (nighttime) due to the cooling properties of tree cover in each census block group.
layer.name: Average reduction in ambient temperature (Celsius)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (total or percent) within each census block group that resides within 300 meters of a busy roadway. A “busy” roadway in EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Residential population within 300m of busy roadway

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the total population within each census block group that resides within 300 meters of a busy roadway that is buffered by less than 25 percent or greater than 25 percent tree cover within 26 meters of a road edge. A “busy” roadway in EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Residential population within 300m of busy roadway with &#119987 percent tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent of busy roadway in each census block group that  is bordered by less than 25 percent or greater than 25 percent tree cover within 26 meters of a road edge. A “busy” roadway in  EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Percent of busy roadway bordered by &#119987 percent tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the reduction in surface runoff as (m3/yr) or percent each year within each census block group due to the presence of trees.
layer.name: Reduction in annual runoff due to tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps show mean rental rates for land on record by county, measured in $/acre for approximately 2008-2016, for irrigated farmland, non-irrigated farmland, or pastureland.
layer.name: Mean rental rate per acre for farm land, 2008-2016

layer.eaDescription: These maps show the percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as cropland on areas with slopes greater than or equal to three percent and nine percent.
layer.name: Percent pasture on slopes

layer.eaDescription: These maps show the percentage of land area within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is classified as pasture on areas with slopes greater than or equal to three percent and nine percent.
layer.name: Percent cropland on slopes

layer.eaDescription: These maps provide modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen and phosphorus dissolved in surface runoff at the outer edges of all agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N or P for 2002. They include nitogen and phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in surface runoff from agricultural fields (tons)

layer.eaDescription: These maps provide modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen and phosphorus dissolved in sub-surface (lateral) flow at the outer edges of tile-drained agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N or P for 2002. They include nitrogen and phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in tile drain subsurface flow from agricultural fields (tons)

layer.eaDescription: These maps provide modeled estimates of the movement (flux) of nitrogen and phosphorus attached to soil particles eroding from the surface of the agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N or P for 2002. They include nitrogen and phosphorus from fertilizer application and atmospheric deposition.
layer.name: Nutrients attached to eroding surface soil from agricultural fields (tons)

layer.eaDescription: These maps provide modeled estimates of nitrogen and phosphorus leachate, i.e., mass of nitrogen or phosphorus dissolved in percolate moving downward out of the soil layer underlying agricultural fields within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in metric tons of N or P for 2002. It does not necessarily reflect the amount of nitrogen or phosphorus that actually enters an underlying groundwater reservoir.
layer.name: Dissolved nutrients in leachate from agricultural fields (tons)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the millions of gallons of water consumed or withdrawn daily for thermoelectric power generation in each subwatershed (HUC-12) for 2016. Thermoelectric power creates electricity through steam powered turbines. This map is based on water withdrawn that is consumed without being returned to the watershed.
layer.name: Thermoelectric water use

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the total land area in square meters or the percent in the 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Land area in 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the total land area in in square meters or percent  in the  0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Land area in 0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the total impervious surface area in square meters or percent in the 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Impervious surface in 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the total impervious surface area in square meters or percent in the 0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Impervious surface in 0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the total or percent population living in the 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Population in 1% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the total or percent population living in the 0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area in each census block group for 2017.
layer.name: Population in 0.2% Annual Chance Flood Hazard area

layer.eaDescription: These maps identify surface water, the riparian zone surrounding surface water, and the hydrologically connected zone, which includes areas of high water accumulation connected to surface water.
layer.name: Waterscape

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the number and density of roads crossing streams in the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Roads Crossing Streams

layer.eaDescription: These maps model rare amphibian species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Rare amphibian species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model rare bird species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps are based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Rare bird species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness during the summer for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Summer bird species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the maximum number of NatureServe Globally Ranked Species (G1, G2, and G3) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) . G1 species are critically imperiled, G2 species are imperiled, and G3 species are vulnerable. This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The maximum number does not represent the potential richness for the entire watershed.
layer.name: Modeled G1, G2, G3 species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the maximum number of species listed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC). This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The maximum number does not represent the potential richness for the entire watershed.
layer.name: Modeled IUCN threatened terrestrial vertebrate species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the maximum number of rare mammal species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US . Rare species were the 25% of mammal species with the smallest amount of predicted habitat. This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The maximum number does not represent the potential richness for the entire watershed.
layer.name: Rare mammal species richness

layer.eaDescription: Thiese maps depict an index value of Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation (PARC) species richness for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) . These species are listed as either threatened and endangered, G1-G3 or IUCN. G1 species are critically imperiled, G2 species are imperiled, and G3 species are vulnerable. This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The index value is based on average values determined for each HUC.
layer.name: Modeled Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation (PARC) species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the maximum number of species listed by Partners in Flight as common species in steep decline that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) . This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The maximum number does not represent the potential richness for the entire watershed.
layer.name: Common bird species in steep decline

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict an index value of rare reptile species richness for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US . Rare species were the 25% of reptile species with the smallest amount of predicted habitat. This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The index value is based on average values determined for each HUC.
layer.name: Rare reptile species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the maximum number of rare terrestrial vertebrate species that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US . Rare species were the 25% of vertebrate species with the smallest amount of predicted habitat. This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The maximum number does not represent the potential richness for the entire watershed.
layer.name: Rare vertebrate species richness

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness during the winter for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). This map is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Winter bird species richness

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted discharges within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC)  for 2011.
layer.name: Total permitted discharges

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted pollutant loadings for metals parameters within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Permitted metals discharges

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of permitted loadings for priority pollutants within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Permitted priority pollutant discharges

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of aggregated nitrogen discharges within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011, in pounds. This includes all parameters for total nitrogen, organic nitrogen, total Kjeldahl nitrogen, nitrite, nitrate, and ammonia. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Permitted nitrogen discharges (pounds per year)

layer.eaDescription: The total reported amount of aggregated phosphorus discharges within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011, in pounds. All phosphorus and phosphate pollutant parameters are included. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Permitted phosphorus discharges (pounds per year)

layer.eaDescription: The reported discharge counts for total coliform, streptococci, E. coli, and enteric viruses in colony-forming units per 100 milliliters within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. These parameters are reported in units that cannot be expressed as a mass discharge, and thus are not included as total load calculations. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Permitted pathogen indicator discharges (colony-forming units / 100 ml)

layer.eaDescription: The reported flow of treated wastewater discharges from POTWS (publicly-owned treatment works) and non-POTWs within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. (Source: ICIS-NPDES)
layer.name: Wastewater flow discharges

layer.eaDescription: These maps show the average annual frequency of cyanobacterial blooms observed in freshwater lakes during 2018.
layer.name: Cyanobacterial harmful algal bloom frequency (2018)
